newsitem.title: UK: Tate, Argos in FTSE relegation zone.
newsitem.headline: Tate, Argos in FTSE relegation zone.

text.p: Sugar group Tate & Lyle Plc and retailer Argos Plc are in the front line of stocks most likely to be relegated from the FTSE 100 when the committee managing the blue chip index meets next Wednesday.

Market capitalisations at next Tuesday's close of those two companies and their peers will decide who ascends to the index and who drops out to make way for them, in the quarterly rejig of the FTSE 100 and London's other indexes.
At Thursday's London close, Tate had a market value of just 1.936 billion stg, followed by Argos at 1.942 billion.
Just above those two were building materials group Hanson Plc, valued at 1.959 billion, and medical supplies group Smith & Nephew Plc at 2.033 billion.

Leading the pack to advance from the FTSE 250, the second division index of mid-ranking stocks, was property group British Land Plc, valued at 2.554 billion stg and caterer Compass Group Plc at 2.294 billion.
Also poised to join the premiership were Southern Electric Plc at 2.106 billion and fund manager Invesco Plc at 1.186 billion.

Changes will formally take effect on March 24, said a spokeswoman for FTSE International -- a joint venture between the Financial Times and the London Stock Exchange which administers UK stock indexes.

Traditionally, membership of the FTSE 100 is regarded as bestowing a higher international profile to individual stocks. Its members are also likely to be bought by "tracker" funds which aim to simply match the performance of leading indices.
Yet more recently stocks have tended to dip in the immediate wake of having joined the index, having already been heavily bought in the run-up to their entry.
In the last quarterly adjustment of index members in December, fund manager Mercury Asset Management Plc and business services group Hays Plc were added to the FTSE 100.
They replaced chemicals group Courtaulds Plc and glassmaker Pilkington Plc.
